hookPresence: Examine the image to determine if there is a hook, such as an intriguing headline, emotional appeal, or other attention-grabbing elements. Respond with True if a hook is present, otherwise respond with False. Respond only with True or False. The response should be a Boolean, make sure of it.
OfferPromotionPresence: Inspect the image for any indication of an offer or promotion, such as discounts, limited-time offers, or similar promotional elements. Respond with True if an offer or promotion is present, otherwise respond with False. Respond only with True or False. The response should be a Boolean, make sure of it.
isCtaAvailable: Analyze the image and determine if a call to action (CTA) element, such as a button, text, or symbol prompting action, is present. Respond with True if a CTA. Respond only with True or False. The response should be a Boolean, make sure of it.
interactivity: Review the image to see if it suggests or encourages user interactivity, such as clickable elements or prompts. Respond with True if interactivity is suggested, otherwise respond with False. Respond only with True or False. The response should be a Boolean, make sure of it.
productPresence: Examine the image and identify if there is a product featured. Respond with True if a product is visible, otherwise respond with False. Respond only with True or False. The response should be a Boolean, make sure of it.
logoPresence: Analyze the image and determine whether there is a visible logo. Respond with True if a logo is present, otherwise respond with False. Respond only with True or False. The response should be a Boolean, make sure of it.

definitions.Product Display: Ads whose primary focus is on visually showcasing the product itself—its look, packaging, styling or use in a “hero” shot—without people or heavy messaging.
definitions.UGC: Ads featuring real users or customers (self‑shot videos, photos, unboxings) demonstrating or talking about the product in an authentic, unscripted style.
definitions.Hook/Offer: Ads that lead with a compelling attention‑grabber or promotional deal—discounts, “limited time,” “buy one get one,” urgency hooks, free gift offers, etc.
definitions.Testimonial/Social Proof: Ads built around customer testimonials, reviews, ratings, influencer endorsements or any element that shows other people’s approval or success stories.
definitions.Product Feature: Ads highlighting one or more specific features, functions or technical benefits of the product (e.g. “waterproof,” “10‑hour battery,” “eco‑friendly materials”), often with callouts or overlays.

contentThemes.classificationPrompt:
You are a tag‑generation assistant.
Input: An image or video of an ad creative (text, voice‑over, or storyboard).
Task: Determine which of the following categories the ad belongs to. It may belong to multiple categories.

Categories:
- Product Display
- UGC
- Hook/Offer
- Testimonial/Social Proof
- Product Feature

Instructions:
1. Understand the ad creative carefully.
2. Assign all categories that apply.
3. Output only valid JSON with a single field, “tags”, whose value is an array of the exact category names.
4. Do not include any other fields, explanations, or punctuation.

Example output:
{"tags":["Product Display","Hook/Offer","Product Feature"]}

Now classify the following ad creative:

colorPalette:
Identify dominant and accent colors visible in the image. Extract between 3 and 6 colors total. Output strictly valid JSON array of objects as follows:
[
  {"color_name": "navy blue", "hex_code": "#000080", "role": "dominant"},
  {"color_name": "beige", "hex_code": "#F5F5DC", "role": "accent"}
]
Rules:
- Use lowercase descriptive color names (e.g., navy blue, pale pink).
- Provide verified hex codes.
- Each object must contain fields: color_name, hex_code, and role (either 'dominant' or 'accent').
- Do not include commentary or text outside of JSON.
visualThemes:
Identify the image’s visual style themes that describe design aesthetics only (not emotion). Return strictly valid JSON:
{
  "themes": ["modern", "vibrant", "photo_realistic"]
}
Rules:
- Choose up to 5 short tags.
- Tags must come from these groups:
  - design_era: modern, retro, vintage, minimalist, futuristic, classic
  - color_mood: vibrant, muted, monochrome, warm, cool
  - texture_style: flat, glossy, grainy, 3d, illustrated, photo_realistic
- Return only JSON, no sentences or markdown.
objects: Identify key objects in the image, providing one to five words per point, separated by commas. Focus on object prominence, relevance, and contribution to the message. Provide keywords or short phrases only. Example Output: – Woman, cocktail, slot machine, neon lights.
peopleDemographics: Describe the people in the image, if any, using one to five words per point, separated by commas. Focus on demographics such as gender, age. Provide keywords or short phrases only. Example Output: – Young Male adult, Age 20 to 30 years
textAmount: Evaluate the text amount in the image, with observations in one to five words per point, separated by commas. Note text density, readability, and balance with visuals. Provide keywords or short phrases only. Example Output: – Minimal text, highly readable, balanced layout.
textOverlayStyle: Analyze the style of the text overlay in the image in one to five words per point, separated by commas. Note font, color, placement, and effects. Provide keywords or short phrases only. Example Output: – Bold font, blue text, top-right corner.
brandIntegration: Observe brand integration in the image, with details in one to five words per point, separated by commas. Note placements like foreground, background, embedded, or prominently displayed. Provide keywords or short phrases only. Example Output: – Subtle hint, top left corner, small size.
backgroundElements: Identify background elements in the image in one to five words per point, separated by commas. Note urban or natural scenes, abstract patterns, or textures and their impact. Provide keywords or short phrases only. Example Output: – Casino setting, neon lights, slot machines.
vfx: Identify visual effects (VFX) in the image, if any, in one to five words per point, separated by commas. Note CGI, 3D rendering, motion blur, overlays, filters, and effects used. Provide keywords or short phrases only. Example Output: – Motion blur, overlay, neon glow effect.
cameraMovement: Identify any camera movement in the image in one to five words per point, separated by commas. Note movement types like tracking, panning, tilting, or motion blur. Provide keywords or short phrases only. Example Output: – Static, no movement, clear focus.
narrativeStyle: Analyze the narrative style in the image in one to five words per point, separated by commas. Note storytelling structures like testimonial, journey, humor, or suspense. Provide keywords or short phrases only. Example Output: – Storytelling, problem-solution, emotional appeal.
emotionalTone: Identify the emotional tone of the image in one to five words per point, separated by commas. Note moods like playful, joyful, dramatic, or nostalgic. Provide keywords or short phrases only. Example Output: – Joyful, vibrant, casual, friendly.
cta: Identify calls to action (CTAs) in the image in one to five words per point, separated by commas. Note CTA forms like button, text, or symbol, and engagement design. If no CTA is present, respond explicitly with -No CTA present. Example Output: – Bold CTA, clickable, red button, urgency OR No CTA present.
hook: Examine any hook in the image in one to five words per point, separated by commas. Identify hooks like bold statements, emotional appeal, humor, or shock value. Provide keywords or short phrases only. Example Output: – Bold statement, emotional appeal, eye-catching.
targetAudienceTraits: Describe traits of the target audience based on the image in one to five words per point, separated by commas. Note age, gender, cultural background, interests, lifestyle. Provide keywords or short phrases only. Example Output: – Young adults, tech-savvy, urban lifestyle.
culturalRelevance: Observe cultural relevance in the image in one to five words per point, separated by commas. Note symbols, traditions, language, or themes meaningful to the target audience. Provide keywords or short phrases only. Example Output: – Pop culture references, youth appeal.
contextualTagsByBusiness: Analyze the image and generate contextual tags that are relevant from a business perspective. Identify keywords that relate to the product features, services offered, brand values, industry sector, marketing campaign themes, competitive advantages, target market, unique selling propositions, and any relevant business strategies. Provide keywords or short phrases only. Example Output: – Eco-friendly, luxury, minimalistic, tech.
productName: Analyze this product image and generate relevant tags that describe the key elements of the product. Focus on keywords related to the product type, brand, target audience, features, benefits, functionalities, materials, sizes, colors, usage occasions, design or aesthetic qualities, and any unique selling points. Provide the tags in the form of bullet points.
brands: Examine brand integration in the image in one to five words per point, separated by commas. Note brand cues like logo placement, product usage, or colors. Provide keywords or short phrases only. Example Output: – Prominent logo, central placement, brand colors.
platformSpecificFeatures: Identify platform-specific features in the image, if any, in one to five words per point, separated by commas. Note aspect ratios, native elements, or platform-focused design choices. Provide keywords or short phrases only. Example Output: – Swipe up, mobile-friendly, native layout.
useOfSymbolsAndIcons: Identify symbols, icons, or visual shorthand in the image in one to five words per point, separated by commas. Note if they clarify meaning, enhance interest, or provide cultural references. Provide keywords or short phrases only. Example Output: – Icons, clear meaning, brand logo.
depthOfField: Observe depth of field in the image in one to five words per point, separated by commas. Note shallow or deep focus, visual hierarchy, and focal emphasis. Provide keywords or short phrases only. Example Output: – Shallow focus, blurred background, subject highlight.
offerPromotion: Identify any offers or promotions in the image in one to five words per point, separated by commas. Note elements like discounts, limited-time offers, or exclusivity. Provide keywords or short phrases only. Example Output: – Limited time, exclusive offer, 20% off.
ctaStyle: Identify any calls to action (CTAs) in the image in one to five words per point. Specify if the CTA is in the form of text, button, or symbol, and describe its emphasis and design for engagement. Ensure the response eliminates duplicate or redundant observations. Provide concise and unique keywords or short phrases only. Example Output: – Bold text, large button, high contrast, click here.
ad_type: Return exactly one word: image or video. If you cannot determine, return an empty string.
influencer: Is an influencer/creator visibly featured as a focal human presenter? Answer True or False only. Consider face/body presence, direct-to-camera delivery, or clear creator-led narration.
what_was_the_content: You are an ad-content tagger. From the provided media, extract 3–7 concise tags that describe the ad’s core content strictly from what is visible/audible (no speculation). Use ONLY this controlled vocabulary (lowercase, underscores): unboxing, tutorial, how_to, demo, testimonial, humor_skit, behind_the_scenes, lifestyle, product_shot, packshot, comparison, before_after, review, asmr, founders_story, influencer_endorsement, ugc, sale_promo, limited_time_offer, giveaway, countdown, fashion_lookbook, runway, try_on, makeover, tips_tricks, cooking_demo, recipe, diy, vlog, interview, timelapse, stop_motion, animation, meme, explainer, app_walkthrough. Rules: no words outside the list; no generic terms (advertisement, content, photo, video); no brand names unless clearly legible and central; if nothing applies with high confidence output exactly: unknown. Format: comma-separated, lowercase, no spaces, no preface/suffix. Order tags by prominence (most central first). Examples — Input: creator opens sealed phone box, shows accessories, talks to camera → Output: unboxing, product_shot, demo. Input: split-screen comparing two moisturizers with ‘Day 1 vs Day 7’ text → Output: comparison, demo, before_after. Input: static pack photo with “-30% today only” banner → Output: packshot, sale_promo, limited_time_offer. Now return only the tags for the current media.
count_of_products_showcased: Count how many distinct products are clearly showcased (packaging, logo, or unique SKU). Return only a number as plain text (0, 1, 2, ...).

axis_ConsumerTimelineLifeEvents.definition: Moments in a person’s journey that shape needs or timing (e.g., new patient onboarding, post-op recovery, annual checkups, open enrollment, new job/role, relocation, clinic launch).
axis_ConsumerTimelineLifeEvents.classificationPrompt: Decide if the creative uses a Consumer Timeline/Life Event based ONLY on visible/legible cues (onscreen text, overlays, dates, timelines, obvious situations). OUTPUT STRICTLY EITHER an array of specific values (e.g., ["new patient onboarding","post-discharge"]) OR null if none are clearly present. No other fields, no extra text. Include 1–3 precise values if and only if evidence is clear; otherwise return null.

axis_SeasonalCulturalTriggers.definition: Time-bound seasons, holidays, observances, or culturally specific moments (e.g., flu season, year-end, Diwali, Christmas, Ramadan, Breast Cancer Awareness Month).
axis_SeasonalCulturalTriggers.classificationPrompt: Determine if the creative leverages a Seasonal or Cultural Trigger using visible cues (holiday terms, seasonal phrases, visuals). OUTPUT STRICTLY EITHER an array of concrete values (e.g., ["flu season","Diwali"]) OR null if absent/unclear. No extra fields. Provide 1–3 values only when clearly evidenced.

axis_TrendBasedViralFormats.definition: Platform-native trends or meme structures (e.g., POV, before/after split, duet/stitch, green-screen explainer, meme caption split, CapCut template, trending sound).
axis_TrendBasedViralFormats.classificationPrompt: Check for Trend-Based/Viral format patterns (POV label, before/after framing, duet/stitch UI, green-screen). OUTPUT STRICTLY EITHER an array of specific values (e.g., ["before/after","POV"]) OR null if none. No extra fields or text. Only include when clearly present.

axis_EmotionalMindsetThemes.definition: Dominant emotions or cognitive frames used to persuade (e.g., relief, trust, urgency, pride, reassurance, competence, FOMO).
axis_EmotionalMindsetThemes.classificationPrompt: Assess whether explicit Emotional/Mindset themes are used (copy tone, badges, headlines). OUTPUT STRICTLY EITHER an array of specific values (e.g., ["relief","trust"]) OR null if unclear/absent. No extra fields. Include 1–3 values only with clear cues.

axis_ContentArchetypesFormats.definition: Structural patterns and creative templates (e.g., how-to, product demo, comparison, testimonial, objection-handling, checklist, myth vs fact).
axis_ContentArchetypesFormats.classificationPrompt: Identify Content Archetypes/Formats from structure and overlays (e.g., steps, side-by-side compare, quoted testimonial). OUTPUT STRICTLY EITHER an array of specific values (e.g., ["how-to","testimonial"]) OR null if not evidenced. No extra fields. 1–3 values max.

axis_CustomAxis_SocialProof.definition: Brand-specific pillar for social proof/credibility (e.g., star ratings, review quotes, case counts, client logos, press badges, ROI metrics).
axis_CustomAxis_SocialProof.classificationPrompt: Detect Social Proof signals (★★★★★, review snippets, “X practices served”, logo bar, press badges, quantified outcomes). OUTPUT STRICTLY EITHER an array of specific values (e.g., ["star ratings","logo bar"]) OR null if absent. No extra fields. Include only with clear evidence.
